Anansi gives 
 people stories 
 
 Ghanaian folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long, long ago, the Sky God, Nyame, kept
 al stories locked in a woden box, high
 
 in the sky. 
 
 People down on earth had no stories to
 
 tel and they were very sad. 
 
 
 They asked Anansi the clever Spider to
 help them. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi spun a long thread, and climbed 
 up his sticky thread al the way to 
 
 heaven. 
 "Can I have the stories, please?" he asked 
 the Sky God. 
 
 But Nyame laughed at Anansi and said, 
 "Oh, these are very expensive stories. 
 
 You wouldn't be able to pay for them, 
 litle spider." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "How much do the stories cost?" asked
 Anansi. 
 
 "You'l have to bring me thre rare and
 fierce animals," Nyame answered, "A
 leopard with sharp teth like spears, a
 
 hornet that stings people, and a snake
 that swalows people whole." 
 
 He laughed and laughed. He thought his
 stories were quite safe. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Anansi climbed slowly back down his 
 
 sticky thread to the earth. He thought 
 and he thought, and he came up with a 
 
 plan. 
 
 He dug a dep hole, covered it with 
 
 branches and dirt so it was hiden, and 
 he went home for super. In the morning, 
 
 sure enough, a leopard had falen into his 
 pit. He was furiously scratching at the 
 side of the pit, but he couldn’t get out. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "Oh let me help you, my dear friend!" said
 
 Anansi. "Just lie down on these sticks
 and I’l pul you out." 
 
 
 Anansi wound his sticky web round the
 leopard and the sticks, and puled him up
 to heaven to show the Sky God. 
 
 But Nyame just laughed and said, "Where
 are the other two?" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Anansi went back down to earth to 
 
 get the second creature. He thought and 
 he thought and he came up with a plan. 
 
 
 He tok a gourd ful of water and went to 
 the tre where the hornets lived. He 
 
 poured out some of the water al over 
 their nest. Then he cut a leaf from a 
 
 banana tre and held it over his head, 
 and he poured the rest of the water al 
 over himself. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He caled out to the hornets, "Hey
 hornets! Come se! It is raining! Quick -
 
 get inside my gourd and it wil kep al of
 you dry." 
 Hornets don’t like to get wet, so they al
 
 flew into Anansi's gourd. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then Anansi quickly spun a web acros 
 the opening so the hornets couldn't get 
 
 out no mater how much they buzed. 
 
 He caried them up to heaven and 
 
 showed them to the Sky God. 
 But Nyame just said, "Where's the last 
 
 one?" (He wasn't laughing so much 
 anymore.) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Anansi went down to earth again. He
 thought and thought and he thought, but
 
 he couldn’t come up with a plan. So he
 asked his wife, who had a very god
 
 idea. 
 
 Together they found a god long thick
 
 branch and some strong vines. 
 When they got near the stream where the
 
 snake lived, they began to argue.
 "The branch is longer!" 
 "No, it isn’t!" 
 
 "Yes it is!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Son the snake came out and asked 
 what the argument was. 
 
 "I was arguing with my wife," said Anansi. 
 "She says this stick is longer than you 
 are. But I don’t agre." 
 
 "Of course I’m longer than that stick!" 
 said the snake. 
 
 "I'm very long! I'm a huge snake! Just put 
 your stick next to me and measure!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Anansi did that, and he tied the snake
 to the stick with his vine to kep him
 
 straight. 
 
 When he was al tied up, Anansi tok the
 
 snake up to heaven. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nyame had to admit that Anansi had 
 paid his price. So he went to his woden 
 
 box, opened the lid, and gave al the 
 stories to Anansi. 
 
 
 Anansi caried the stories triumphantly 
 down to earth. 
 He shared them with his wife, and with 
 
 al the other animals and people. 
 
 
 Stories are for teling, not for keping in 
 woden boxes.
